meta_description: Projects, writings, and experiences of Tolga Kurt. Personal website of a Mathematical Engineering student.
og_description: Personal website where I share my projects and what I have learned.
twitter_description: Personal website where I share my projects and what I have learned.

I share what I do.
Github / LinkedIn
home_intro_1:
You are looking at a website where I do and record things that are on my mind and/or that I want to archive.
This website is the first website I made myself, and some blessings like AI have been utilized in its creation.
In the texts that appear this way, you can hover over the text for detailed information.
You can use the navigation section, which is on the right on computers and above on mobile, to browse between pages.
who_am_i_details:
I'm a student of Mathematical Engineering at Yildiz Technical University.
I'm Turkish.
I'm interested in foreign languages; philosophy, ideas, thoughts; etymology; mathematics; board and box games, systems, orders, and creating my own;family trees, connections; religions, religious stories; space; self-sufficient houses or organizations or systems like self-sufficient home.
My English is around B1 level. I have an A1 certificate in French. I completed a 120-hour face-to-face Turkish sign language course. I finished my A1 Japanese education, I will finish A2 soon. In high school, I studied German but don't know more than a few words.
who_am_i_details_hint1_title: Visually. Who is a relative, what degree, etc.
who_am_i_details_hint2_title: Like solar panels; like growing cucumbers and tomatoes.
who_am_i_details_hint3_title: Worse than B2, not worse than B1, undocumented
cv_intro: (This section is taken directly from my CV empty at the time it was written.)
rmbivd_title: Randomly Moving Balls in Various Dimensions
rmbivd_intro_3: I don't know the answer to that, but I can code it.
rmbivd_intro_4: If masses do not have a tendency to disperse, they will always meet again at the origin.
rmbivd_intro_5: If masses disperse too quickly, then there would be no ground to stand on.
rmbivd_intro_6: Let's analyze the dispersion and convergence rates of masses moving randomly in different dimensions.
rmbivd_1d_title: Balls Moving Randomly in One Dimension
rmbivd_1d_math_p1: In a one-dimensional environment, there is 1 axis and 2 directions.
rmbivd_1d_math_p2: A ball can move in the +x (right) or ‚àíx (left) direction.
rmbivd_1d_math_p3: At each step forward, the balls are split into two groups: half go right, half go left.
rmbivd_1d_math_p4: Here is the source code and result showing the step-by-step perfect behavior:
rmbivd_1d_random_title: Balls Moving Randomly in One Dimension
rmbivd_1d_random_p1: Here is a sample output produced using the source code I wrote:
rmbivd_1d_random_p2: Now let's run it a few times and check the results. The following abbreviations are used:
rmbivd_2d_title: Balls Moving Randomly in 2D
rmbivd_2d_p1: As I showed in the notes I prepared, balls move one unit in a direction that can be any mix of the two axes.
rmbivd_2d_p2: From (0,0), a vector drawn to a random point on the unit circle defined by x<sup>2</sup> + y<sup>2</sup> = 1 sets the motion. The new position is the sum of the current position and the vector.
rmbivd_2d_p3: For x<sup>2</sup> + y<sup>2</sup> = 1, choose x randomly in ‚àí1 to +1; then y is the sign variant that makes the length 1; in short: y = ¬±‚àö(1 ‚àí x<sup>2</sup>).
rmbivd_2d_conclusion: A decrease in TBMGS and EA1KGO is observed.
rmbivd_3d_plus_title: Balls Moving Randomly in 3 and More Dimensions
rmbivd_3d_p1: The equation becomes x<sup>2</sup> + y<sup>2</sup> + z<sup>2</sup> = 1. y = ¬±‚àö(1 ‚àí x<sup>2</sup>) and z = ¬±‚àö(1 ‚àí x<sup>2</sup> ‚àí y<sup>2</sup>).
rmbivd_3d_conclusion: Decrease is observed in TBMGS and EA1KGO.
rmbivd_4d_conclusion: Decrease is observed in TBMGS and EA1KGO.
rmbivd_results_p1: In 1D, EA1KGO is close to 100%, in 2D nearly 60‚Äì65%, in 3D 20‚Äì25%, in 4D about 5‚Äì10%.
rmbivd_results_p2: In 1D, substances drifting away and forming new clusters seems unlikely.
rmbivd_results_p3: In 2D, substances can move away, but most tend to return, causing clustering at the center; if you also think about gravity, this may not be ideal for universe formation.
rmbivd_results_p4: In 3D, most substances do not return to the center, but those who do are still significant in number.
rmbivd_results_p5: In 4D, very few substances return to the center‚Äîthey disperse very quickly.
rmbivd_results_p6: Perhaps these balls are telling us why our universe exists in three dimensions, not where substances disperse too quickly nor hardly at all. Or maybe I'm just making things up. Who knows!
rmbivd_todo_li1: Add a simple gravity model (acceleration towards center).
rmbivd_todo_li2: Re-adjust parameters (step count, sample size) and compare results.
rmbivd_todo_li3: Add literature references about the topic.
